author: Ulrich Geupel
loc_justification: Set on Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, as a reference point for the variety targeted, namely north-eastern Gheg as spoken roughly in Kosovo.

author: Martin Macak
variety: Western Armenian literary language, ultimately closely related to the dialect of the Erzerum area.
loc_justification: Set in the town of Erzurum, formerly a major dialect area of Western Armenian in Asia Minor, and ultimately closely related to the Western Armenian literary language effectively based on the dialect of Constantinople (Istanbul).

author: Martin Macak
loc_justification: Set in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, the dialect of which historically forms the basis of colloquial Eastern Armenian and is the most widespread of the Armenian dialects today.

author: Patrycja Markus
loc_justification: Set on Kolkata (Calcutta), capital of the Indian state of West Bengal, and a cultural centre where Bengali is the dominant language.

description: Standard Bulgarian
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Sofia, as the capital of Bulgaria

description: Standard Belarusian
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Minsk, as the capital of Belarus

author: Kim Schulte
loc_justification: Set roughly on the geographical centre of Catalonia, given that standard Catalan (the variety represented in IE-CoR) is purposely based not on a single dialect.

description: Standard Czech
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Prague, as the capital of the Czech Republic

author: Tonya Dewey
variety: Standard Danish, as spoken around Copenhagen.
loc_justification: Set in Copenhagen, generally considered the region closest to the perceived 'standard' form of Danish.

author: Annemarie Verkerk
loc_justification: Set on the approximage geographical centre of the Randstad, intermediate between the four main cities of Holland (Amsterdam. Rotterdam, The Hague and Utrecht), the region whose dialect was most influential in the development of modern standard Dutch.

author: Martin Findell & Paul Heggarty
variety: British English, in majority usage in England.
loc_justification: Set on Oxford, popularly considered a prestige location of the perceived standard variety of English in (southern) England, and where lexical usage corresponds to the lexeme determinations in the IE-CoR data for English.

author: Tonya Dewey
loc_justification: Set on Tórshavn, capital of the Faroe Islands, and a roughly central location among the islands and their corresponding dialects.

author: Tonya Dewey
loc_justification: Set at the approximate mid-point of the Flemish-speaking regions of Belgium, on the border between the two more central dialects, East Flanders and (South) Brabant.

author: Paul Heggarty
variety: Standard, with lexical usage of north-central France.
loc_justification: Set in Tours, traditionally and still widely considered among French-speakers as a region whose (pronunciation) is close(st) to the perceived 'standard' language.  More relevant for IE-CoR is its location within north-central France, where lexical usage generally corresponds most closely to the entries in this IE-CoR data for French.

author: Paul Versloot
loc_justification: Set roughly at the transition between the main surviving dialects, Klaaifrysk and Wâldfrysk.

description: 'Hochdeutsch' standard German, particularly as spoken in (north-central) Germany.
author: Cassandra Freiberg
loc_justification: Set on Hannover.  Although without particular linguistic merit, Hannover is at least widely considered among German-speakers as a region whose (pronunciation) is close(st) to the perceived 'standard' language.  More relevant for IE-CoR is simply that Hannover is in a fairly central location within northern Germany, where lexical usage generally corresponds most closely to the lexeme determinations in the IE-CoR data for German.o

description: Contemporary Standard Modern Greek.  Transliterations follow ISO 843 TL. For phonological interpretation cf. Holton, Mackridge, and Philippaki-Warburton (2012)
author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: Athens, the capital city of the present day Hellenic Republic.

description: Hindi:  the official language of India, and a lingua franca for almost all of nothern India.
author: Krzysztof Stroński
loc_justification: Set on Delhi, India

author: Tonya Dewey
loc_justification: Set in Reykjavík (on the Árni Magnússon Institute), as the capital of Iceland, given the general perception that dialectal variation by geography is in any case minimal.

description: Modern standard as interpreted by a Galway speaker
author: Cormac Anderson
loc_justification: Set at south Galway provenance of primary coder

author: Cormac Anderson and Matilde Serangeli
variety: Standard (originally based on the Florence dialect of Dante)
loc_justification: Set in Florence, the dialect of which historically formed the basis of standard ‘Italian’.

description: This is essentially a northern variety of Kashmiri of the Kashmir valley, with respect to more divergent regional forms such as Poguli and Kashtawari spoken outside of the valley. However, this particular sub-variety is the one spoken on the Pakistani-administered side of the Line of Control.
author: Khawaja Rehman
loc_justification: Set on Sharda (Neelum valley, Azad Jammu & Kashmir), the home of the main language consultant for these IE-CoR data.

author: Paul Videsott
loc_justification: Set on the border between Trentino and South Tyrol, a geographically central point of the area in which Ladin is spoken.

author: Tijmen Pronk
loc_justification: Standard Latvian is based on the Vidzeme subdialect of the Middle dialect. The coordinates are those of the village of Mūrmuiža near Valmiera, Latvia, close to where Jānis Endzelīns, one of the founders of the Latvian norm, was born.

author: Tijmen Pronk
loc_justification: Standard Lithuanian is based on the West Aukštaitian dialect. The coordinates are those of the village of Rygiškiai, Lithuania, where Jonas Jablonskis, one of the founders of the Lithuanian norm, grew up.

description: West Slavic minority language spoken in eastern Germany
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Chóśebuz (Cottbus), the historical capital of Lower Lusatia

description: West Slavic minority language spoken in eastern Germany
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Budyšin (Bautzen), the historical capital of Upper Lusatia

description: Marathi:  the official language of  the Indian state of Maharashtra, and one of the 22 scheduled languages of India. The data for this work was based on the standard Marathi spoken in Pune.
author: Mandar Purandare and Krzysztof Stroński
loc_justification: Set on Pune, India.

description: Nepali:  the official language of Nepal, as well as one of the 22 recognized languages of India, and an official language of the Indian state of Sikkim
author: Krzysztof Stroński
loc_justification: Set at Kathmandu, the capital of the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal and the major educational, cultural and literary centre for Nepali.

author: Arash Zeini
loc_justification: City of Tehran, capital of modern Iran

description: Standard Polish
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Warsaw, as the current capital of Poland

author: Kim Schulte
loc_justification: Set in Coimbra, in the area between Figueria da Foz and Guarda, popularly considered to be where “the best” Portuguese is spoken.  In particular, Coimbra, as home to the oldest and most venerable university in Portugal, plays an important role in establishing what is accepted in the standard language.

author: Steve Pepper
loc_justification: Set on Oslo, since Bokmål was originally based on the ‘Dano-Norwegian’ spoken by the ‘urban elite’, especially in Oslo.

author: Kim Schulte
loc_justification: Set in the Carpathians (the Bucegi mountains south of Brașov), as the transition between southern and Transylvanian dialects of Romanian.

description: Standard Russian
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Moscow, as the capital of Russia

description: Logudorese dialect
author: Simone Loi
loc_justification: Set roughly in the geographical centre of the Logudoro-speaking area.

description: Nuorese (Bitti) dialect (a conservative variety of Logudorese)
author: Simone Loi
variety: Nuorese (Bitti) dialect (a conservative variety of Logudorese)
loc_justification: Set on the town of Bitti (Bitzi), the dialect used for the IE-CoR data for Nuoro Sardinian.

author: Roland Pooth
loc_justification: Set on Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka and the cultural centre of the country, where standard Sinhala is a primary language.

description: Standard Slovak
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Bratislava, as the capital of Slovakia

author: Kim Schulte
loc_justification: Set on Valladolid, at the centre of the region popularly considered to speak the ‘purest’ Spanish, or the variety closest to the rules of the Real Academia Española. This area roughly coincides with the provinces of Salamanca, Valladolid, Palencia and Burgos.

author: Harald Hammarström
loc_justification: Set on Stockholm, a high-prestige dialect on which standard Swedish is heavily based.

description: Standard Ukrainian
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Kiev, given the general perception of the Kiev region as one where the 'standard' form of Ukrainian is spoken.

author: Esther Baiwir
loc_justification: Set in Liège, the variety coded here.

author: Matilde Serangeli
loc_justification: Site of Boğhazkale (Boğhazköy) identified with the Hittite capital Ḫattuša.

description: Tocharian A texts come from the Šorčuq and Turfan areas and do not date before the 7th c. CE. There is continuing debate as to whether the language was still spoken at this time, but there is no evidence that Tocharian A speakers ever lived to the west of Šorčuq. The Turfan texts exhibit a few minor linguistic peculiarities, suggesting that there were once actual living Tocharian A speech communities in both places.
author: Ronald Kim
variety: Tocharian A, the relatively uniform language attested in texts of almost exclusively religious content, from Šorčuq and Turfan.
loc_justification: Set at a point geographically roughly intermediate between the two main areas where Tocharian A texts have been found: Šorčuq and Turfan.

description: Archaic/early Tocharian B of the Kuča region, attested in manuscripts from the 5th and 6th centuries CE.  From Kuča, the language spread to Šorčuq c. 600 CE, and then eastwards to Turfan and (marginally) westwards to Murtuq in the late 7th century CE.  The archaic/early form of Tocharian B, as targeted in the IE-CoR data, is from Kuča, while what is sometimes termed “classical” Tocharian B, represented by the majority of the surviving literary manuscripts, comes from Kuča and sites immediately to its east (Šorčuq, Qarašahr, etc.).
author: Ronald Kim
variety: Archaic/early Tocharian B of the Kuča region.
loc_justification: Set on Kuča, since manuscript evidence indicates that the original location of Tocharian B speakers was Kuča and its environs (including Qumtura and Subashi) — see especially Peyrot (2008).

description: Standard Macedonian
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Skopje, as the capital of Macedonia

description: Standard Serbo-Croat, with transcriptions in Ijekavian pronunciation
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Belgrade, as the capital  of Serbia

description: Standard Slovenian
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Ljubljana, as the capital of Slovenia

description: Late West Saxon Old English
author: Martin Findell

description: Old Church Slavonic as documented in the texts of the strict canon (manuscripts from the 10th and 11th centuries AD)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Thessaloniki (Greece), the hometown of Saints Cyril and Methodius, the creators of Old Church Slavonic as a written language.

author: Roland Pooth
loc_justification: Set at Śalātura, the birthplace of Pāṇini.

author: Tijmen Pronk
variety: Data were taken from the following Old Prussian sources: The three cathechisms, the Elbing vocabulary and Grunau's vocabulary. These sources represent several slightly different dialects of the Old Prussian language.
loc_justification: The coordinates are those of Moxovoe, Kaliningrad Oblast', Russia. It is an archeological site located on the Sambia peninsula, which was one of the last areas where Old Prussian was spoken.

description: Classical Attic. For phonological description and phonetic reconstruction cf. Allen (1987).  Verb forms listed in 1.sg. present indicative unless otherwise specified.  Nouns listed in nominative singular unless otherwise specified.  Transliterations follow the ALA-LC system, with the addition of accentual diacritics.
author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: Site of Classical Athens, the area where the Attic dialect of Ancient Greek originated.

author: Ganesh Gupta
loc_justification: Set on Madhubani, the cultural centre of the Mithila region, the home region of several renowned Maithili poets, among them Vidyapati Thakur, the ‘father of Maithili literature’.

description: Classical Latin (Literary Standard of the Roman Late Republic/Early Imperial Period). Verb forms given in the present infinitive otherwise specified.  Nouns given in nominative singular unless otherwise specified.
author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: Set in Rome.

author: Peadar O'Muircheartaigh
loc_justification: Set at the geographical midpoint of the island of South Uist, the variety targeted here.

description: Northern Kurdish (Kurmanji)
author: Baydaa Mustafa and Geoffrey Haig
loc_justification: Set at Duhok, Iraq, main urban location in which this variety is spoken

description: Urdu:  the official language of Pakistan, as well as one of the 22 recognized languages of India.
author: Krzysztof Stroński
loc_justification: Set on Islamabad, Pakistan

author: Sam Mersch
loc_justification: Set on the approximate geographical mid-point of (the country of) Luxembourg.

author: Giorgio Cadorini
loc_justification: Set in Udine, cultural and political centre of the Friulian language

description: Standard Iron as spoken by the majority of speakers in North Ossetia (specifically, with respect to the sound changes /c/ → /s/, /dz/ → /z/, /s/ → /š/, /z/ → /ž/).
author: Oleg Belyaev
variety: Standard Iron as spoken by the majority of speakers in North Ossetia
loc_justification: Vladikavkaz, the capital of North Ossetia, and roughly the geographical centre of the Iron-speaking area (albeit slightly to the east).

description: The dialect characteristic of the Iræf district, with non-phonemic palatalization of affricates and sibilants before front vowels (cf. /cʼew/ [čʼew] 'bird'). I still chose Digora (Digorskij district) as the location because the data are supposed to represent the whole of the Digor dialect. Also this variety appears to be currently more widespread than the one without palatalization.
author: Oleg Belyaev
variety: The dialect characteristic of the Iræf district.
loc_justification: Digora, the largest Digor-speaking town of Ossetia and also roughly the centre of the modern Digor-speaking area. (The original Digor area was more in the highlands.)

description: 9th century East Franconian
author: Tonya Dewey

description: Primarily based on Old Irish glosses
author: Cormac Anderson
loc_justification: Set at Armagh, primary site of Irish Christianity and centre for Old Irish

author: Thomas Jügel
loc_justification: It is uncertain where Avestan was originally spoken. For further discussion, cf. Humbach, Helmut, Josef Elfenbein & Prods Oktor Skjærvø. 1991. The Gāthās of Zarathushtra and other Old Avestan Texts. Part I: Introduction – Text and Translation Heidelberg: Carl Winter Universitätsverlag

author: Martin Macak
loc_justification: Set in present day Ejmiatsin, formerly also known as Vagharshapat, which was the capital of the Kingdom of Greater Armenia during the period of the earliest inscriptional and literary attestations of Classical Armenian.

author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: South Central Italy. Approximate centre of Oscan speaking areas prior to the historical spread of Latin.

author: Thomas Jügel
loc_justification: Site of Anshan in Elam, the original home city of the Achaemenids.

author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: Modern Gubbio, Italy. Find site of the Iguvine Tables which comprise the main bulk of the Umbrian corpus.

description: Composite list of Cuneiform Luvian (xlu) and Hieroglyphic Luvian (hlu). Cuneiform Luvian and Hieroglyphic Luvian data are indicated respectively as (CL) and (HL) in the Native Script data.
author: Matilde Serangeli
variety: Composite of both well-documented forms:  predominantly Cuneiform, but also some Hieroglyphic Luvian data.of predominantly Cuneiform Luvian (xlu) and Hieroglyphic Luvian (hlu).
loc_justification: Set at a geographically intermediate point between the archaeological sites where the main archives of the Cuneiform and Hieroglyphic forms were found, i.e. respectively Ḫattuša (modern Boğazköy) and ancient Karkamış.

description: Lexeme determinations are difficult because much of our knowledge of the Gaulish lexicon is through analysis of proper names, including personal names, theonyms, and toponyms. Lexeme determinations have been made in cases where it seems clear that a form did indeed have the relevant meaning synchronically in Gaulish, including cases where this is an inference from proper names. For extensive discussion of the difficulties in determining lexeme meanings in Gaulish, see the introduction to Delamarre's Gaulish lexicon.
author: Britta Irslinger
loc_justification: Gergovia, stronghold of the Arverni

description: Kâmkata-vari comprises two major dialects, Kâmviri and Kâta-vari, named after the ethnonyms of their speakers, the Kom and the Kâta.  Kâta-vari itself comprises two major dialects, Eastern Kâta-vari and Western Kâta-vari, of which the former is more conservative.  Kâmkata-vari has been misnamed "Kati" and "Bashgali" in older literature, without regard to the dialects.
author: Richard Strand
variety: The Eastern Kâta-vari dialect of Kâmkata-vari.
loc_justification: Location of the main community, Barg-i Matâl (Břagʹamâṭol).

description: Adjectives are cited with the accompanying (sort of) article: i for masculine and e for feminine. Nouns are cited in their indefinite forms. Due to a lack of infinitive, verbs are cited in the 1st person singular active indicative.
author: Michiel de Vaan
loc_justification: Set on the city of Elbasan, whose historical variety is a transitional dialect that features both Gheg and Tosk elements and was used as a first standard language in the early 20th century.  This had an important impact on what was since further development into today's standard language, and although not completely identical with it, remains close to the modern standard.

description: Magahi is spoken mainly in Bihar and Jharkhand, along with some parts of West Bengal and Orissa. The data for this work was collected from the variety of Magahi spoken in and around the capital city of Patna, Jehanabad and Gaya.Although linguistically Magahi is different from Hindi (it does not even belong to same sub-family,as is clear from the Grierson's classification), the Indian government classifies Magahi as a dialect of Hindi. Despite this attitude, a large population (counting up to 13,978,565 according to the Census of India, 2001) residing in villages and small towns still speak and use the language astheir medium of communication and information-sharing (Alok et al 2011).
author: Ganesh Gupta
loc_justification: Set on Patna, the capital of the Indian state of Bihar, the major town in which Magahi is spoken.

author: Lars Steensland
loc_justification: Set in the town of Älvdalen (Övdaln).

author: Christopher Lewin
loc_justification: Set at Tynwald Hill, traditional meeting place of the Manx parliamentary assembly

author: Britta Irslinger
loc_justification: Set at approximate midway point between Lomarec and Gomené inscriptions

author: Alexander Falileyev
loc_justification: Tywyn, location of the Cadfan stone

description: Last living relic of Doric, spoken in the towns of Kastanitsa, Sitena, Prastos, Leonidi, Pramatefti, Sapounakeika, Tyros, and Melana, possibly also still in Korakovunio, on the east coast of the Peloponnese.
author: Nikos Liosis
loc_justification: Set on the village of Leonidio (Λεωνίδιο), the de facto capital of the Tsakonian region.

author: Tonya Dewey
loc_justification: Set on the approximate midpoint of the province of Västergötland (West Gothland), since the main early texts for Old Swedish are the legal codes for this region, the Västgötalagen.

author: Martin Kümmel
loc_justification: It is difficult to give an exact original location for Pāli, but the location as given is set to reflect the dominant Western MIA characteristics of Pāli. It is set here at Ujjain, historical capital of Avanti, realm associated with Pāli (Warder, A. K. Indian Buddhism. 2000). For further discussion cf. Norman, K. R. 2002. "Pāli and the languages of early Buddhism" In Indo-Iranian Languages and Peoples, ed. by N. Sims-Williams, 135-50. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

author: Britta Irslinger
loc_justification: Set on Saint-Paul de Léon, the historical capital of the Léon region.

description: Mycenaean Greek from Linear B sources.
author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: Archaeological Site of Mycenae. Other major archive centres were Knossos, Pylos, Tiryns, and Thebes.

description: Eastern Middle Iranian of Khotan, Southern Silk Road (now Hotan in China)Written in South Turkestan Brahmi script
author: Martin Kümmel
loc_justification: Set on Hotan, the capital of the Kingdom of Khotan, in which Khotanese was spoken.

description: West Slavic minority language spoken in Poland. Central Kashubian as spoken in the western part of this dialect area in the vicinity of Serakòjce (Sierakowice)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on the village of Sierakowice, the largest town in the Central-West Kashubian dialect area

description: Extinct West Slavic language documented in a few sources from the turn of the 17th to 18th centuries AD
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set in Klennow (near Wustrow), the home village of the main informant for the richest available documentation of Polabian, by Christian Hennig von Jessen.  For details, see Polański & Sehnert (1967: 15).

description: Strictly confined to the variety of Roman-period koiné Greek that is attested in the New Testament corpus.  Other varieties of Jewish koiné Greek (e.g. in the Septuagint translation of the Hebrew scriptures) are not included.
author: Matthew Scarborough
loc_justification: Site of Jerusalem in Roman Palestine.

description: Middle Persian as found in Manichaean texts from Central Asia, written in Manichaean script. In contrast to Zoroastrian "Pahlavi" writing reflects the actual phonology much better, and this variety also appears to be more strictly "Persian" (less loans from NW Iranian). Phonologization follows Durkin-Meisterernst and MacKenzie.
author: Martin Kümmel
loc_justification: Site of Persian capital Persepolis

description: Middle Northwestern Iranian language, attested parallel to Middle Persian in Manichaean texts. A very restricted  corpus of older inscriptions from Iran also exist. Early Parthian (or related languages) were the main source for Middle Iranian loanwords in Armenian.Phonologization follows Durkin-Meisterernst 2004, except for <c>,<ž> and <j>, whereI have applied the findings of Korn 2010 (Bulletin of SOAS, 73/3, 415–436), i.e. <c>=<z> = /č/, <j> = /ž/ [ʒ ~ dʒ]
author: Martin Kümmel
loc_justification: Set on modern-day Nisa, Turkmenistan, an archaeological site of a fortress associated with Arsaces I (r. 247–217 BCE), the first king of Parthia and the founder of the Arsacid dynasty.

description: Extinct variety of Tsakonian formerly spoken at a Tsakonian colony in the Propontis region of Asia Minor. Speakers of Propontic Tsakonian were relocated to various areas of Greece following the population exchanges of 1922, and later shifted to Standard Modern Greek.
author: Nikos Liosis
loc_justification: Location of a former Tsakonian colony in the Propontis region of Asia Minor. Cf. Tsakonian dialect map in Liosis, Nikos. 2016. "Tsakonian Studies: The State-of-the-Art" Μελέτες για την ελληνική γλώσσα [Studies in Greek Linguistics] 36 : 205-17.

author: Giovanni Abete
loc_justification: Set in Naples.

author: Tijmen Pronk
loc_justification: The coordinates are those of the town of Rēzekne in the centre of Latgalia.

author: Christodoulou Charalambos
loc_justification: Approximate centre of the Greek Cypriot administered region of Cyprus.

description: Modern Italiot Greek. Note this list contains both Calabrian and Apulian forms.
author: Nikos Liosis
loc_justification: Region of Calabria, one of two main locations along with Apulia where modern Italiot varieties of Hellenic are spoken in present day.

author: Heather Pagan
loc_justification: Set in Westminster, traditional venue for the coronation of English monarchs since Norman times.

author: Stephen Dworkin
loc_justification: Set on Toledo, since the IE-CoR data for Old Spanish are centred on texts from the royal chancellery of Alfonso el Sabio (reigned 1252-1284 CE) in Toledo.

author: Nikola Vuletić
loc_justification: Set on the town of Krk, on the island of the same name, where the Vegliote variety was spoken

author: Sabine Tittel
loc_justification: Set in Paris, cultural and political centre of the area in which Old French was spoken.

author: Nikos Liosis
loc_justification: Area roughly corresponding to location of villages where present day Cappadocian Greek dialects are spoken.

author: Nikos Liosis
loc_justification: Geographical co-ordinates between Of and Çaykara in Trabazon province, the two regions with the largest numbers of Pontic Greek speakers in Anatolia.

description: Vâsi-vari is spoken in the six villages of the Pârûn Valley.  Each village has its own dialect.  Vâsi-vari has been called "Prasun" and "Paruni" in the literature, but these are not native names.
author: Richard Strand
variety: The dialect of Vâsi-vari spoken in Paṣki.
loc_justification: Location of the lowest community in the Pârûn Valley, Paṣki (Uṣʹüt).

description: Kâmkata-vari comprises two major dialects, Kâmviri and Kâta-vari, named after the ethnonyms of their speakers, the Kom and the Kâta.  Kâta-vari itself comprises two major dialects, Eastern Kâta-vari and Western Kâta-vari.  Among other changes, Western Kâta-vari has lost vocalic nasalization, which is retained in the other dialects.  Kâmkata-vari has been misnamed "Kati" and "Bashgali" in older literature, without regard to the dialects.
author: Richard Strand
variety: The Western Kâta-vari dialect of Kâmkata-vari, as spoken in the Ktivi Valley of central Nûristân.
loc_justification: Location of the main community, Kântivâ (Ktʹivi).

description: Kâmkata-vari comprises two major dialects, Kâmviri and Kâta-vari, named after the ethnonyms of their speakers, the Kom and the Kâta.  The Kom, at least, are most probably descendants of the ancient Kamboja people, known since the 6th century BCE.  Kâmkata-vari has been misnamed "Kati" and "Bashgali" in older literature, without regard to the dialects.
author: Richard Strand
loc_justification: Location of the main community, Kâmdesh (Kʹombřom).

description: Âṣkuṇu-Saṇu-viri comprises the dialects of three ethnic groups that inhabit portions of upper Laghmân and across the watershed in the middle Pech Valley.  Saṇu-viri is the dialect of the Saṇu people, centered on the village of Wâmâ in the Pech.  Âṣkuṇu-Saṇu-viri has been called "Ashkun" in previous literature, after the Âṣkuṇu people of upper Laghmân.
author: Richard Strand
variety: Saṇu-viri, the dialect of Âṣkuṇu-Saṇu-viri spoken in Wâmâ.
loc_justification: Location of the main community, Wâmâ (Sâma).

description: Kalaṣa-alâ consists of two major dialect groups, one comprising four villages of the upper Wâigal Valley plus four villages in adjacent valleys, the other including five villages in the lower valley.  Each village has its own sub-dialect.  The dialect of Nišeigrâm is the major one of the lower dialect group.  Kalaṣa-alâ has been called "Waigali" after the name of its home valley, but properly that name should denote only the dialect of the major village of the upper valley,Vâigal.
author: Richard Strand
variety: Nišei-alâ, the dialect of Kalaṣa-alâ spoken in Nišeigrâm.
loc_justification: Location of the main community, Niše'i (Nišeigrâm).

description: The best described variety and the ’standard for ongoing orthography development.
author: Henrik Liljegren
variety: Southern Palula (Ashreti), one of two main dialects
loc_justification: Set on Ashret (Chitral district), the largest Palula settlement and home of the main language consultant for these IE-CoR data.

description: Franco-Provençal (‘Arpitan’) refers to the Alpine varieties of Romance spoken in parts of Switzerland (Suisse Romande), Italy (Val d’Aosta) and France (Savoy).  Not to be confused with Provençal, spoken in the Provence region of south-eastern France.
author: Jérémie Delorme
loc_justification: Set at the meeting point of the borders of Switzerland (Suisse Romande), Italy (Val d'Aosta) and France (Savoy), the regions of all three countries where Franco-Provençal is spoken.

description: Gorakhpuri
author: Ganesh Gupta
loc_justification: Set on Gorakhpur, the town where the IE-CoR Bhojpuri data were elicited, and the centre of the Gorakhpuri dialect, one of the main dialects of Bhojpuri

author: Steve Hewitt
loc_justification: Set on Tréguier, capital of the historical region of Treger.

author: Nicholas Williams
loc_justification: Set on Mousehole (Porthenys), the most probable location of the last native speakers of Cornish.

author: Nicholas Williams
loc_justification: Set on Glasney College in Penryn, where many of the core surviving texts in Middle Cornish, particularly ‘Miracle plays’, were composed.

author: Loïc Cheveau
loc_justification: Set on Vannes, historical capital of Gwened

author: Guto Rhys
loc_justification: Approximate mid-point of the northern dialect area of Welsh.

description: Old Polish as documented in the dictionary Słownik Staropolski (1953-2002)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Gniezno, as the oldest capital of Poland

author: Alexander Falileyev
loc_justification: Approximate midway point between provenance of White Book of Rhydderch and Red Book of Hergest

author: Erik Anonby
loc_justification: These are the coordinates for the town of Kumzar, the historical, political and cultural centre of the language.

description: Old Czech as documented in dictionaries and corpora published at http://vokabular.ujc.cas.cz
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Prague, as the capital of historical Bohemia

description: Historical Slavic variety from northern Russia, markedly divergent from Old Russian proper, showing some features that are entirely absent in all other historical and modern Slavic varieties
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Velikij Novgorod

description: East Slavic minority language spoken in the Carpathians and surrounding regions, showing (depending on the particular dialect) admixtures of West and South Slavic features. Rusyn as spoken in Toruń (Transcarpathian Ukraine) and documented by Nikolaev & Tolstaâ (2001)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on the village of Toruń in the Transcarpathia (Zakarpattia) province of Ukraine

description: The Visoka dialect of Macedonian, as described by Małecki (1936)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on the village of Visoka/Osa in the Thessaloniki region of Greece.

description: The Suho dialect of Macedonian, as described by Małecki (1936)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on the village of Suho/Sochos in the Thessaloniki region of Greece.

author: Mortaza Taheri-Ardali and Erik Anonby
loc_justification: These are the coordinates for the town of Ardal, where the language data were collected.

description: Based on the dictionary of Kastelec & Vorenc from 1680-1710 (Stabej 1997)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on Ljubljana, as the capital of Slovenia

description: Kostel dialect (belonging to the Lower Carniolan dialect group) as documented in the dictionary by Gregorič (2015)
author: Lechosław Jocz
loc_justification: Set on the settlement of Kostel, the historical centre of the Lower Carniola region

author: Manuel Widmer
loc_justification: Set on Bern.

author: Shirin Adibifar and Raheleh Izadifar
loc_justification: Sari, Iran, main urban centre in which this variety is spoken

description: Punjabi:  one of the major languages of Pakistan, as well as one of the 22 recognized languages of India, and an official language of the Indian state of Punjab.
author: Liudmila Khokhlova
loc_justification: Set on Amritsar, state of Punjab, India

author: Nicholas Sims-Williams
loc_justification: Set on Samarkand, one of the principal cities of ancient Sogdiana.

author: Patrycja Markus
loc_justification: Set at Raha, Nagaon province, provenance of the informant from whom the data were elicited

author: Masoud Mohammadirad, Raheleh Izadifar, and Geoffrey Haig
loc_justification: Set at Javanrud, Kermanshah province, Iran, provenance of the speaker from whom the data was elicited

author: Maryam Nourzaei and Shirin Adibifar
loc_justification: Zahedan, Iran, main urban centre in which this variety is spoken

author: Raheleh Izadifar
loc_justification: Set on Takestan, Qazvin, Iran, the main urban centre where this variety is spoken.

author: Nicholas Sims-Williams
loc_justification: Set on Balkh, ancient capital of Bactria.

author: Muhammed Ourang and Erik Anonby
loc_justification: Set on the town of Ahel, where the IE-CoR data were collected.

author: Fatemeh Nemati
loc_justification: Set on Delvar township, Bušehr province, Iran, main urban centre where this variety is spoken.

author: Petar Atanasov
loc_justification: Set to a geographically central location within the area in which Megleno-Romanian is spoken

author: Parvin Mahmoudveysi
loc_justification: Set at Parveh, Iran, main urban centre in which this variety is spoken

description: There is in fact only very slight dialect variation considering how widespread the language is, but due to only recent expansion.
author: Asfar Ali Khan and Henrik Liljegren
loc_justification: Set on Mastuj (Chitral district), one of the oldest centres of the language and home of the main language consultant for these IE-CoR data.

author: Mojtaba Gheitasi and Erik Anonby
loc_justification: These are the coordinates for Ilam, the town where the language data were collected.

author: Borana Lushaj
loc_justification: Set on the village of Caraffa di Catanzaro in Calabira, toe 'toe' of Italy, the variety targeted here.

author: Adam Benkato
loc_justification: Set in the area formerly of the lower reaches of the river Amu Darya (Oxus) south of the Aral Sea, ancient Khwarazmia.

description: This is not a true dialect division, more a recent divergence effect from the international border (Pakistan/Afghanistan) cutting through the region where the language is spoken.
author: Henrik Liljegren
loc_justification: Set on Arandu (Chitral district), the main Gawarbati town on the Pakistani side of the border and home of the main language consultant for these IE-CoR data.

author: Maria-Reina Bastardas
loc_justification: Set on the monastery of Poblet, where the abbot commissioned the Catalan version of the Llibre dels Fets, the primary source material for the IE-CoR entries for Old Catalan.

description: The best described variety and the ’standard for ongoing orthography development.
author: Muhammad Zaman Sagar and Henrik Liljegren
variety: Kalam Kohistani, representing one of two main varieties (of Swat and Dir, respectively)
loc_justification: Set on Kalam (Swat district), the main Gawri town and home of the main language consultant for these IE-CoR data.

author: Mahnaz Talebi and Erik Anonby
loc_justification: These are the coordinates for the town of Barzok, where the language data were collected.

author: Muhammad Kamal Khan
loc_justification: Provenance of primary coder near Swabi in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan.

description: Pashai forms a large and messy dialect continuum, and any dialect/language division is prone to oversimplification. The present division of Pashai into north-west, south-west, north-east and south-east  is based on Morgenstierne (1967), but there are numerous sub-divisions that complicate the picture.
author: Henrik Liljegren
variety: North-western Pashai as spoken in Dawlat Shah
loc_justification: Set on Dawlat Shah (Laghman province), the home of the main language consultant for these IE-CoR data.

author: Matthew Boutilier
variety: East Franconian, the dialect of the Old High German Tatian text.
loc_justification: Set on the monastery of Fulda, where the major reference text in Old High German, the translation of Tatian, is widely assumed to have been produced.

author: Deborah Kim and Timothy Palmer
loc_justification: Location of the county seat of the Tashkorgan Tajik Autonomous County, main urban centre where Sarikoli is spoken.

author: Matthew Boutilier
variety: The text of the epic poem Hêliand.
loc_justification: Set on Bremen, an important early city central within the region where Old Saxon was spoken.

author: Matthew Boutilier
variety: West Saxon dialect of Old English
loc_justification: Set on Winchester, as the reference point for the best documented dialect of Old English, sometimes even referred to as the "Winchester standard".

author: Matthew Boutilier
loc_justification: Set on Stuttgart, a major city in the Swabian-speaking area, given that the ‘standardised’ written form of Middle High German (the ‘Dichtersprache’) was generalised from the spoken language of Swabian area.

author: Matthew Boutilier
loc_justification: Set on Eindhoven, the capital of modern Noord-Brabant and close to the centre of historical Brabant, a central dialect area and the most influential dialect in the Middle Dutch period.

author: Matthew Boutilier
loc_justification: Set at Þingvellir. the venue of the Alþingi, Iceland's historical parliament.

author: Matthew Boutilier
variety: The text of the Gothic Bible as translated by Wulfila.
loc_justification: Nicopolis ad Istrum. Although original to northern Europe, by the date at which Gothic language was first written down, in the form of Wulfila's translation of the Bible into Gothic, Wulfila and his Gothic-speaking followers were settled in the Roman province of Moesia, around Nicopolis ad Istrum (near Veliko Tarnovo in north-central Bulgaria)
